cont.entity_a: Excellent for flush cuts. Blade stays sharp for a long time.
cont.entity_b: Extremely thin. Requires careful attention for straight cuts.

cont.entity_a: Performs well on crosscuts but struggles with ripcuts. Suitable for cutting dowels and flush trims. Cuts quickly and accurately. Zero tooth offset is ideal for flush cutting. Thin kerf and easy control for detailed cuts.
cont.entity_b: High accuracy with little waste when cutting on the pull stroke. Not suitable for dovetails due to blade flexibility. Leaves grooves in wood.

cont.entity_a: Replacement blades are nearly as expensive as a new saw. Blade is removable, but replacement is not cost-effective.
cont.entity_b: Affordable replacement blades held firmly by a plastic screw.

Size.comm: Light and small, good for small projects.

cont.entity_b: Lightweight and flexible, ideal for small tasks.

cont.entity_a: Aggressive teeth require care for accurate cuts. Blade protector helps keep teeth sharp.
cont.entity_b: Sharp teeth but brittle and break easily.

cont.entity_a: Simple but lacks a guard, posing safety risks.
cont.entity_b: Plastic handle is functional but feels cheap. Could be better designed for tight flush cuts.

cont.entity_a: Blade can be damaged by nails or staples. Not sturdy; flimsy blade affects precision.
cont.entity_b: Blade is not reinforced, not ideal for dovetails. Not ideal for heavy-duty use; blade bends easily.

cont.entity_a: Works well for soft and hard woods.
Not suitable for unsupported straight cuts in thick stock.
